Exaggerate: The claim may be exaggerating the cost of high-speed rail to Florida taxpayers by stating it would have cost $1 billion to build. This is because the claim does not provide enough support or evidence to back up this specific cost.
Understate: There is no evidence of understatement in the claim.
Falters at times: The claim does not falter at times as it consistently states that high-speed rail would have cost Florida taxpayers $1 billion to build.
Lack enough support: The claim lacks enough support or evidence to substantiate the $1 billion cost of high-speed rail to Florida taxpayers. It only provides statements from Florida Governor Rick Scott and the rejection of federal money, but does not provide any concrete data or analysis.
Problematic assumption: The claim assumes that high-speed rail would have cost Florida taxpayers $1 billion to build without providing sufficient evidence or analysis to support this assumption.
Exist alternative explanation: There is no alternative explanation provided in the claim.
Contradict fact: The claim does not contradict any known facts.
